content.webTitle: Alex Salmond speech – first minister hits back over Scottish independence

fields.body:
2.10pm GMT

Here’s Nicholas Watt’s news story on the Salmond speech.

That’s it from me for the day. Thanks for all the comments.

1.22pm GMT

Alistair Darling, the leader of the no campaign, has put out this statement in response to Salmond’s speech:

Alex Salmond is pretending the last week never happened. It is now simple fact that Scotland cannot keep the pound if we leave the UK. Alex Salmond has a responsibility to tell us what will replace the pound. Will we set up a separate unproven currency or will we be rushing to join the euro?

Alex Salmond was arguing against about a problem of his own making - the problem of transaction costs for business due to changing currency. Avoiding extra costs to business and not placing jobs at risk are powerful reasons why we should vote to remain in the UK and keep the pound.

Leaving the UK and losing the pound will cost jobs, raise mortgage rates, increase credit card prices and make people’s weekly shop more expensive.

12.50pm GMT

He says there are no splits in the yes campaign over what will happen to the currency.

12.49pm GMT

The polls have been pretty stable, Alexander says, and come down for the union. But he is not complacent, he says.

12.49pm GMT

Salmond is going to try over the next 200 days to hide from Scots what will happen with the currency, Alexander claims. That “beggars belief”.

12.49pm GMT

Salmond is saying: “We want you to go for independence, but there is no map and no destination,” Alexander claims.

It’s very important that Scots have some facts, he says.

12.47pm GMT

He says the Lib Dems, Labour and Conservatives all agree that a currency union would not be good for Scots or for the remaining UK.

12.47pm GMT

Alexander is asked about Westminster politicians “bullying” Scots.

He denies there is any bullying. He is a Scot and has a vote, he says.

12.45pm GMT

But none of the alternatives to a currency union are very appetising, Alexander says.

12.45pm GMT

Danny Alexander, the Lib Dem chief secretary to the Treasury, is being interviewed on BBC News at the moment.

He says Salmond does not have clear answers to the questions raised by Osborne, Barroso, Carney and others. He should have stood up and said a currency union won’t happen - here’s my plan B, Alexander says.

12.43pm GMT

The Scottish government has issued a number of papers following Salmond’s speech, about the costs it says the rest of the UK would face if it did not go into a currency union with Scotland.

One paper claims the remaining UK would face costs of £500m.

Another challenges the no campaign’s claim that a currency union would limit Scotland’s economic independence.

On transaction costs to UK businesses, the Scottish government says:

Scottish government analysis illustrates that a separate Scottish currency has the potential to lead to transaction costs for rUK [the remaining UK] businesses of approximately £500m per year.

This cost would be incurred by industry and customers in rUK importing and exporting from an independent Scotland with an alternative currency.

This illustrative calculation uses estimates from research on costs and benefits of European Monetary Union to the value of trade between rUK and Scotland.

The second paper outlines 44 key economic levers in taxation, public spending, regulation and institutions, and representation an independent Scotland would gain.

These include power over corporation tax and income tax, regulatory levers in competition and consumer protection, control over spending on welfare and infrastructure, representation in the EU, international trade organisations and an independent foreign policy.

12.30pm GMT

Here’s some Twitter reaction to Salmond’s speech:

12.11pm GMT

If there was a new currency, people would want to know: “what’s it going to be worth tomorrow?” Darling says.

Salmond’s threat to default on Scotland’s share of the UK date is very irresponsible, Darling says.

And people know enough about Europe to know jobs depend on membership, he says.

With that the interview concludes.

12.10pm GMT

Alistair Darling, the former chancellor who is leading the no campaign, is being interviewed on BBC News now.

He says the trend among opinion polls is that sentiment has “barely moved” since the Scottish government published its white paper on independence.

But he is not complacent and has always said this would be closer than people think, he says.

That said, “the wheels are coming off the nationalist wagon”, he says.

People in the yes campaign are at odds over what to do about the currency, Darling says.

12.08pm GMT

Salmond says Scotland wants to raise its own money, govern its own spending, but share a currency - “why not?”

Asked about Barroso’s comments, Salmond points out that the EU is always expanding. His comments were “fantastic”. This was not an issue for the European commission, and anyway Barroso is retiring. The EU will respect a democratic vote from Scotland.

12.06pm GMT

Salmond says there has been an emotional reaction in Scotland to last week’s team-up by the three Westminster parties. But this is also about the head, as well as the heart, he says.

12.05pm GMT

Salmond refers to Osborne as making a “grab for the Bank of England”.

12.05pm GMT

Just before I do that, Salmond is being interviewed on Sky News now.

He says Osborne is “daft” to be suggesting something - that Scotland would not be able to keep the pound - that would hurt UK businesses too.

He refers to the UK’s debt as something that “George Osborne and Alistair Darling have built up over the last few years”.

12.02pm GMT

Summary

Alex Salmond has been speaking out after a week of attacks over whether an independent Scotland would be able to keep the pound or remain in the EU. Here are the key points from the Scottish first minister’s speech:

• Salmond said George Osborne’s arguments against Scotland keeping the pound were based on a “caricature” of macroeconomic policy. Many of the issues Osborne had raised had already been answered by the fiscal commission working group, a group of advisers analysing the issues an independent Scotland would have to deal with. London-based financial assets would always have to be backed by London even if Scotland were independent, he said. If Osborne did not allow Scotland to share the pound he would be in effect imposing a “George tax” of hundreds of millions of pounds on businesses in the remaining UK.

• He renewed his threat to reject Scotland’s share of the UK’s debt if Edinburgh did not receive its share of the UK’s assets, including the Bank of England ie the currency.

• He said he was confident the EU would find a pragmatic way to allow Scotland to become a member. To not do so would go against the grain of the union’s democratic values. The real threat to Scotland’s place in the EU came from the Tories’ plans to hold a UK-wide in/out referendum, Salmond said.

• He said that politically it had been a mistake for Labour and the Liberal Democrats to team up with the Conservatives to try to tell Scotland what it could and could not do. But he was sure that after a yes vote negotiations between an independent Scotland and the rest of the UK would become constructive again as economic sense and self-interest prevailed.

• In Osborne’s speech, the chancellor referred to an independent Scotland as a foreign country, Salmond recalled - but the rest of the UK would never be a foreign country to Scots, the first minister said.

I’ll look at how the speech went down in Scotland and the rest of the UK now.

11.48am GMT

The BBC has just cut away from Salmond (Sky did so earlier), but I heard a round of applause there so he may have finished anyway.

I’ll sum up the key points made by the first minister shortly.

11.46am GMT

Salmond is asked if there are people at Westminster who have a reasonable approach with whom the yes campaign can do business.

Salmond says there are. The Edinburgh agreement setting up a referendum promised a constructive discussion.

He says people don’t like the sight of the three Westminster parties combining to dictate terms to Scotland.

But he repeats his point that he is sure that the day after a yes vote negotiations will become constructive again.

11.41am GMT

We have to separate campaign rhetoric from economic sense and self-interest that will prevail the day after a yes vote, Salmond says.

11.40am GMT

Would the UK have a balance of payments problem if Scotland left, a woman asks.

Salmond says the speech on Scotland by David Cameron at the London Olympic park where he touched on this was described as a “charm offensive” towards Scotland - but this was replaced a few days later by an “offensive” from Osborne.

To lose the key Scottish industries would seem an extraordinary thing for any chancellor to want to do (by stopping Scotland from having the pound), he says.

11.38am GMT

A businessman with a business in Germany says he is worried about Scotland finding itself outside the common market - if the Tories hold a referendum on EU membership and the UK decides to leave.

Salmond says Scotland has been part of the EU for 40 years and wants to continue. But the UK wants to rewrite the central treaties of the EU and have an in-out referendum. He suggests Scotland’s negotiations on these matters will be more successful than the UK’s.

The real threat to Scotland’s position in the EU comes from Eurosceptic politics at Westminster, he says.

11.35am GMT

That’s the end of the speech. Questions will now follow.

11.35am GMT

Salmond calls for a “partnership of equals” with “our closest friends in the rest of the UK”.

That is why we must become an independent country, he concludes.

11.34am GMT

The issue is not whether Scotland could be independent, but whether it should be.

One solution is to leave Westminster in charge. That would leave Scotland in an economic system increasingly concentrating jobs and prosperity in the south-east.

11.33am GMT

The alternative to Osborne is to take control of our own destiny, he says.

The no campaign has no plan for Scotland except to leave it to Westminister and hope for the best.

11.32am GMT

We are a hotbed of success and progress in life sciences; we have a world-class food and drink industry, says Salmond. He also mentions renewable energy and tourism.

11.31am GMT

No one doubts that Scotland can be a successful independent country, he says. Even without the huge bonus of North Sea oil and gas the economy per head is almost the same size of that in the UK as a whole.

Updated at 11.31am GMT

11.30am GMT

Siding with the man dismantling the welfare state and imposing permanent austerity will haunt “the two Eds”, Salmond says (Miliband and Balls).

11.30am GMT

The sight of a Labour shadow chancellor reading from a script prepared by Osborne was too much for some Scottish Labour people, and drove some of them into the arms of the yes campaign.

11.29am GMT

There is an inherent unfairness in what Osborne is suggesting, he says. People do become sick and tired of a succession of Conservative ministers flying up to give a speech and then flying back, but on top of that no one with a semblance of understanding of the Scottish character would have made such a speech. To be told we can’t do things gets the reply from Scots: “Yes, we can.”

11.28am GMT

The Scottish government’s position is based on goodwill, he says.

He says the Scottish government is willing to accept the share of liabilities as long as it gets a share of assets - including the Bank of England.

11.26am GMT

If there is no legal basis for Scotland having a share of the Bank of England, as Osborne suggested, there is no legal basis for Scotland taking a share of the national debt, Salmond says.

11.25am GMT

Osborne attacked Scotland for financial management, yet the UK has borrowed a “mindboggling” £780bn since 2005. In contrast since 2007 the Scottish government has lived within a balanced budget, he says.

11.24am GMT

This was not an economic assessment, but a campaign tactic, he says.

11.23am GMT

Osborne also downplayed the “thirty thousand million pounds contribution” from Scottish oil and gas, he says.

11.23am GMT

The chancellor said you don’t need to be in a currency union to trade between nations – but, says Salmond, this might be very costly, hundreds of millions of pounds, he says, calling this the “George tax”.

That would be impossible to sell to British businesses, he says.

11.21am GMT

London-based assets would have to be secured by the London government whether Scotland is independent or not, he says.

Osborne said he was concerned about a sharp fall in the oil price. In fact the fiscal commission working group recommended a stabilisation fund that would resolve that problem, Salmond says.

11.19am GMT

He turns to the case Osborne made against Scotland keeping sterling.

Osborne did not engage with the fiscal commission working group and caricatured their views, he says. This was a contrast with Bank of England governor Mark Carney in his “excellent” speech on the subject of sterling, Salmond says.

Osborne cited the size of the Scottish financial sector, but the figures he used were wrong, Salmond says. The Treasury inflated the Scottish financial sector by allocating London-based assets to Scotland - for example the RBS markets division.

11.16am GMT

The decision is one for member states, but not to recognise Scotland’s democratic will would run counter to the spirit of the EU, Salmond says.

No member state has suggested they would seek to block Scottish membership, he says.

The Scottish government has always been willing to take part in discussions and negotiations.

11.15am GMT

He says the same democratic logic will apply to Barroso’s comments too. EU law requires all parties to negotiate in a spirit of good faith and cooperation, Salmond says. The EU will find a pragmatic way to accommodate Scotland.

11.13am GMT

He says this negativity shows why the no campaign is called “Project Fear”.

11.12am GMT

If there is a yes vote, Salmond says he is sure that spirit of constructive cooperation will return. But for now, during the campaign, that has gone.

Salmond says Osborne talked about Scotland as a foreign country. In fact, Salmond says, whether independent or not, Scotland will never regard the rest of the UK as a foreign country. The same was true when Ireland became independent, he says.

11.11am GMT

Both governments have agreed to respect the outcome of the referendum, Salmond recalls.

11.10am GMT

Salmond says Osborne warned previously that the Scottish referendum would cause inward investment to drop - in fact it has gone up, he says.

11.09am GMT

He says he wants to address George Osborne’s remarks about the pound.

He wants to discuss the politics of the three Westminster parties teaming up on this issue, and claims that has backfired.

Finally, he says Scotland must become independent if the country is going to advance.

11.08am GMT

He says the Scottish government intends to continue to be constructive and positive about the future of the country - in contrast to Westminster politicians.

11.08am GMT

He says he wants to set out four points of importance as Scots make up their minds.

11.06am GMT

Salmond is speaking now.

10.58am GMT

Salmond’s deputy, Nicola Sturgeon, has already hit back after European commission president José Manuel Barroso said it would be difficult, if not impossible, for Scotland to join the European Union.

Sturgeon said Scotland could join the EU by March 2016, adding:

The decision on Scottish independence is for the Scottish people and the decision about continuing membership of the European Union is for the member states. It is a not a decision for the European commission.

What Barroso was saying what that he did not think other member states would want Scotland to continue in membership and therefore it would be very difficult.

It would be enormously disruptive, not just for Scotland, but for the entire European Union for Scotland to be outside the union. It would also be against the founding principles of the EU because Scotland would be effectively being punished for exercising its democratic right to self-determination

10.51am GMT

Good morning. Alex Salmond is today to make a speech to business leaders in Aberdeen defending some of his key claims for Scottish independence, after a week in which he has come under serious pressure over whether an independent Scotland would be able to keep the pound, and whether it would remain in the EU.

I’ll cover the speech and reaction live here.

Updated at 11.06am GMT
